Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Modeling Multiscale Control of Liver Regeneration

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Liver disease affects millions of individuals each year. Treatment for liver disease often requires a liver transplant due to the inability of damaged liver tissue to regenerate in many cases. A better understanding how liver tissue is renewed and repaired will improve the ability to develop future interventions. Understanding tissue physiology is often complicated by the fact that cells next to each other do not necessarily respond the same manner. Emerging technologies and analysis methods aimed at high-throughput molecular assays of hundreds-to-thousands of single cells have enabled an unprecedented view of the heterogeneity, hierarchy and complexity of cellular functional states. Multiscale modeling is one tool that can aid in understanding the variation in observable cellular behavior, so this research project is developing a novel multiscale modeling framework that takes advantage of the in-depth information on cellular function that can be obtained from these single cell data sets. This modeling framework bridges from the molecular scale to the tissue scale to enhance knowledge gained about physiology and pathophysiology. While the outputs from this model will support improved understanding and manipulation of tissue response to injury in the liver, it will likely be applicable to understanding other tissues as well. The research team is integrating students of all levels, from high school through graduate school, in this project in order to excite them about scientific research and to provide them with professional development opportunities.

The central innovative idea of this project is to realize the full potential of the novel single cell data sets by developing models of cellular functional states and state transitions to bridge the molecular and tissue scales. The team is developing the proposed multiscale modeling framework in the context of understanding the control principles governing the coordinated tissue response to injury. This approach involves explicit accounting of cellular functional states of immune, stromal, endothelial and epithelial cells, and putative molecular processes driving the state transitions, with broad applicability to multiple tissue repair scenarios. The team is focusing on the process of liver regeneration as an enabling testbed in order to fully develop, fine tune and illustrate the multiscale modeling approach for broader application and utility.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The present project is aimed at developing a detailed computer simulation of liver regeneration by using liver cell type-specific gene expression data. During the project period, we obtained a data set from hundreds of single cells isolated from liver after resection surgery in rats. We focused on two liver cell types during the project period: hepatocytes and hepatic stellate cells (HSCs). We analyzed the data and incorporated the results on changes in cellular states into a preliminary computer simulation of liver regeneration.

We sought to characterize the effects of liver resection on the molecular states of individual hepatocytes during the onset and progression of liver regeneration. We optimized a novel technique to collect single cells using laser capture microdissection, and analyzed the expression of 84 genes across 233 individual hepatocytes. Analysis of this single cell data revealed that hepatocyte molecular states can be considered as distributed across a set of four states, with the proportions of hepatocytes in these states changing over time after resection. In addition to the quiescent, primed, and replicating hepatocytes, we identified a novel molecular state, which we refer to as the primed-to-replicating transition state.

We developed a computer simulation model that incorporates state transitions of Kupffer cells, HSCs, and hepatocytes, as well as the dynamics of key cytokines and growth factors, and signaling pathway kinetics in the hepatocytes. The growth factors that can drive proliferation of hepatocytes are considered as a single lumped variable. The return of cell states to quiescence was modeled empirically without any molecular pathway detail as this is still an active area of research in the liver regeneration field. This simulation model accounts for the phenomenology and known involvement of TGFbeta pathway and extracellular matrix remodeling in termination of the liver regeneration, by incorporating a transfer function that empirically relates the extent of remodeled extracellular matrix to the requiescence rate of hepatocytes. Our initial simulations predicted that the relative balance of HSCs between the two active states controls the extent of mass recovery after partial hepatectomy. Interestingly, our experimental results suggest four HSC transcriptional states contributing to liver regeneration, three of which were represented in the model, and two of which are described for the first time in this work. Our results indicate that HSCs influence the dynamics of liver regeneration through steady-state tissue preconditioning prior to an acute insult and through dynamic control of cell state balances.

Taken together, the new experimental findings and computer simulation model illustrate a new approach to study the complex process such as liver regeneration, with potential to extend these results to human condition for prognostic use in liver surgeries. The experimental data and computer simulation model have been published in multiple peer-reviewed manuscripts.

The project involved training of multiple graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in the new experimental and computer simulation methods.
